p: Curcumin, another natural product commonly used in cooking, has been investigated in experimental models of IBD, demonstrating beneficial effects mediated by the suppression of proinflammatory mediators [ 132]. In a randomized, multicenter, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial, curcumin has shown beneficial results in maintenance therapy for patients with UC [ 133]. Although the exact mechanisms by which curcumin may exert a wide range of biological actions have not been established, effects have been attributed to the regulation of histone acetylation/deacetylation and the expression of various microRNAs [ 134].
